article.title: Mercurial
article.text: {{About|the revision control software|the unrelated corporation|Mercurial Communications}} {{Infobox software | name = Mercurial | logo = [[File:New Mercurial logo.svg|frameless|upright]] | developer = Matt Mackall | released = {{Start date and age|2005|4|19|df=yes}} | platform = | genre = [[Version control]] | license = [[GNU General Public License#Version 2|GNU GPL v2+]] | website = | repo = | latest release version = 4.5{{Citation | title = Mercurial | edition = 4.5 | contribution = What’s new | contribution-url = https://www.mercurial-scm.org/wiki/WhatsNew#Mercurial_4.5_.282018-02-01.29 | type = wiki | publisher = mercurial-scm.org}}. | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2018|02|01|df=yes}} | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | operating system = [[Unix-like]], [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[macOS]] | programming language = [[Python (programming language)|Python]] and [[C (programming language)|C]] }} '''Mercurial''' is a [[distributed revision control|distributed revision-control]] tool for [[software developer]]s. It is supported on [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[Unix-like]] systems, such as [[FreeBSD]], [[macOS]] and [[Linux]]. Mercurial's major design goals include high performance and scalability, decentralized, fully distributed collaborative development, robust handling of both [[plain text]] and [[binary file]]s, and advanced branching and merging capabilities, while remaining conceptually simple.{{Citation | contribution-url = https://www.mercurial-scm.org/wiki/Presentations?action=AttachFile&do=get&target=ols-mercurial-paper.pdf | first = Matthew ‘Matt’ | last = Mackall | contribution = Towards a Better SCM: Revlog and Mercurial | place = Ottawa | format = [[Portable document format|PDF]] | title = Linux Symposium Proceedings | year = 2006 | publisher = Mercurial-scm.org}}. It includes an integrated web-interface. Mercurial has also taken steps to ease the transition for users of other version control systems, particularly [[Apache Subversion|Subversion]]. Mercurial is primarily a [[Command line interface|command-line]] driven program, but [[graphical user interface]] extensions are available, e.g. [[TortoiseHg]], and several [[integrated development environment|IDEs]] offer support for version control with Mercurial. All of Mercurial's operations are invoked as arguments to its driver program hg (a reference to Hg - the [[chemical symbol]] of the element [[Mercury (element)|mercury]]). Matt Mackall originated Mercurial and serves as its lead developer. Mercurial is released as [[free software]] under the terms of the [[GNU General Public License#Version 2|GNU GPL v2]] (or any later version {{Citation | publisher = Mercurial-scm.org | contribution-url = https://www.mercurial-scm.org/wiki/Relicensing | contribution = Relicensing | title = Mercurial | type = wiki }}. ). It is mainly implemented using the [[Python (programming language)|Python programming language]], but includes a binary [[diff]] implementation written in [[C (programming language)|C]]. == History == Mackall first announced Mercurial on 19 April 2005.{{cite mailing list | last = Mackall | first = Matt | date = 2005-04-20 | title = Mercurial v0.1 – a minimal scalable distributed SCM | url = https://lkml.org/lkml/2005/4/20/45 | mailinglist = [[Linux kernel mailing list|Linux kernel]] }} The impetus for this was the announcement earlier that month by [[Bitmover]] that they were withdrawing the free version of [[BitKeeper]]. BitKeeper had been used for the [[version control]] requirements of the [[Linux kernel]] project. Mackall decided to write a distributed version control system as a replacement for use with the Linux kernel. This project started a few days after the now well-known [[Git (software)|Git]] project was initiated by [[Linus Torvalds]] with similar aims.{{cite mailing list|url=http://lkml.indiana.edu/hypermail/linux/kernel/0504.3/1404.html|title=Re: Mercurial 0.4b vs git patchbomb benchmark|date=2005-04-29|mailinglist=[[Linux kernel mailing list|Linux kernel]]|last=Mackall|first=Matt|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120709203437/http://lkml.indiana.edu/hypermail/linux/kernel/0504.3/1404.html|archivedate=9 July 2012|df=dmy-all}} The Linux kernel project decided to use [[Git (software)|Git]] rather than Mercurial, but Mercurial is now used by many other projects (see [[#Open_source_projects_using_Mercurial|below]]). "Git vs. Mercurial" has become one of the holy wars of [[hacker culture]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/aix/library/au-mercurial/|title=Managing source code with Mercurial|quote=Mercurial and Git fans are also happy to discuss the learning curve, merits, and usability of each VCS system's command set. Space prevents that discussion here, but a web search on that topic will provide lots of interesting reading material.}} In an answer on the Mercurial mailing list, Matt Mackall explained how the name "Mercurial" was chosen: {{Quotation|Shortly before the first release, I read an article about the ongoing Bitkeeper debacle that described [[Larry McVoy]] as mercurial (in the sense of 'fickle'). Given the multiple meanings, the convenient abbreviation, and the good fit with my pre-existing naming scheme (see my email address), it clicked instantly. Mercurial is thus named in Larry's honor. I do not know if the same is true of Git.{{cite mailing list | last = Mackall | first = Matt | title = Why did Matt choose the name Mercurial? | url = https://www.mercurial-scm.org/pipermail/mercurial/2012-February/041807.html | mailinglist = Mercurial | date = 2012-02-15 | accessdate = 7 June 2016 }}Torvalds has said: ''"I'm an egotistical bastard, so I name all my projects after myself. First Linux, now git."''|}} In 2013, Facebook adopted Mercurial and began work on scaling it to handle their large, unified code repository.{{cite web|last1=Goode|first1=Durham|last2=Agarwal|first2=Siddharth|title=Scaling Mercurial at Facebook|url=https://code.facebook.com/posts/218678814984400/scaling-mercurial-at-facebook/|website=Facebook Code|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=13 October 2015}} == Design == Mercurial uses [[SHA-1]] hashes to identify revisions. For repository access via a network, Mercurial uses an [[Hypertext Transfer Protocol|HTTP]]-based protocol that seeks to reduce round-trip requests, new connections and data transferred. Mercurial can also work over [[Secure Shell|SSH]] where the protocol is very similar to the HTTP-based protocol. By default it uses a [[3-way merge]] before calling external merge tools. == Usage == Figure 1 shows some of the most important operations in Mercurial and their relations to Mercurial's concepts. [[File:Mercurial commandd and their relations.png|thumb|Figure 1: Some important operations of Mercurial and their relations.]] == Adoption == Although Mercurial was not selected to manage the Linux kernel sources, it has been adopted by several organizations, including [[Facebook]],{{cite web|url=https://code.facebook.com/posts/218678814984400/scaling-mercurial-at-facebook/|title=Scaling Mercurial at Facebook}} the [[World Wide Web Consortium|W3C]], and [[Mozilla]]. Facebook is using the [[Rust (programming language)|Rust programming language]] to write [[Mononoke (software)|Mononoke]]{{cite web|url=https://github.com/facebookexperimental/mononoke|title=A Mercurial source control server, specifically designed to support large monorepos}}{{cite web|url=https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/mozilla.dev.version-control/nh4fITFlEMk/|title=Mercurial 4.0 Sprint Notes}}, a Mercurial server specifically designed to support large multi-project repositories. == Mercurial servers and repository management == * [[RhodeCode]] by [[RhodeCode#Company|RhodeCode
